msItem.title: Medical recipe for making a plaster to treat headache
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th-century hand.
Fully transcribed in Mooney (1995), pp. 109-110.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for making plasters to treat migraine headaches
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th-century hand.
Fully transcribed in Mooney (1995), p. 110.

msItem.title: Preface to the translation of Nicholas of Oresme's De moneta
msItem.incipit: 1v To sum it semyth that any king or prince of his owne auctorite may of right or privelage chaunge freely the money rennyng in his realme and of theym at his lust to ordeigne and vpon that to take the lucre profite and wynnyng whatsumeuer it be
msItem.explicit: 1v and com to guydre and aboute that to fynde that to princis and their subgettis þat in althyng most rathest to the publique and comune weele may profite in tyme comyng

msItem.title: Table of contents, or chapters, for the translation of Nicholas of Oresme's De moneta
msItem.rubric: 1v Here bigynnenthe chapitres folowyng a Treatise of the begynnyng of natures lawe and right and chaunges of money
msItem.incipit: 1v The first chapitre wherfor and whi money owgth to be f vijo
msItem.explicit: 2r xxvi. That to take lucre or wynnyng of chaunges of money doeth preiudice to al the Roial power

msItem.title: The Kalender of the chater of London (table of chapters of the Charter of London)
msItem.rubric: 2r A kalender of the charter of london [added by a 16th-century hand]
msItem.incipit: 2r Capitulo jo The shereffhod of london and middilsex leten to ferme to the citezeyns of london for .CCC. pounds
msItem.explicit: 6r Cvj. That the maire from that tyme to come be nat compelled to make any other oth than in tyme of the kyng Edward the .iij. was wont to be don
msItem.note: The lower halves of ff. 6r-6v, 6a recto-6a verso are left blank for additional chapther headings or contents.

msItem.title: De moneta [English translation]
msItem.author: Nicholas of Oresme
msItem.incipit: 7r Whan the highest god divided folkes whan he departed the sones of adam he ordeigned termes of peoplis Therof bien men multiplied vpon the erth and possessions as is expedient thei bien divided Of this forsoth it happith and fallith that oon hath more of oothyng than hym needith
msItem.explicit: 25r But who therfor with love and trowth to lasse piese seyenges wil geynsey or agenst write he may wele do it and if I say evil bere he witnes of evil with reason that he be nat seen freely and voluntarily to condempne that may nat lightly be impugned etcaetera
msItem.finalRubric: 25r Here endith the treatice of chaunge of money

msItem.title: Charter of the City of London as confirmed by Richard II
msItem.incipit: 26r Richard with the grace of god kyng of Inglond and of ffraunce and lord of Irlond to Archebisshoppis Bisshoppis Abbottis and Priours Dukes Erlis Barons Iustices Shereves Provostes Ministres and al Bailiefs and his feithful liegis gretyng we han bihold the Charter of confirmacioun of the holy memorie of the lord Edwarde laate kyng of Inglond oure grandsir in thiese wordis
msItem.explicit: 45r Ergo in London: Also that the Shereves of london whiche for the tyme beyng þe toln and other customs to their forme perteyneng and other open offices to theym longyng and bi other exercised if thei wiln turn hem to men sufficient for whiche tho Shereves wiln aunswer and to nonother bien thei commytted and whosumever bi the forsaide Shereves to any of the premysses deputed he or any other hym berath or vndue custom takith in that office other wise than hym owght and at the sute of the pleintief therof be convict from that office be he amoeved and taken awey and after his demerites be he [crossed out: he] punysshed
msItem.note: As noted by Mooney (1995), p. 110, the text does not appear to follow the order of that of the table of contents on ff. 2r-6r. Mooney identifies the text's source as the inspeximus charter of Richard II, April 12, 1377, or its reiteration in 1384.

msItem.title: Memorandum of law of Robert Billesdon, Mayor, and the Aldermen of London in the second year of Richard III (1484), concerning translation from one craft to another
msItem.incipit: 45v Memorandum that the xxvij day of august the ijde yere of the reign of kyng richard the iijde it is aggreed bi robert billesdon mair and thaldremen of the cittee of london to eschewe the discencions which myght happyn betwene craftes of this cittee that from hensforth no translacioun be made from one craft to another withowte the consent of the mair and the aldremen of the said cittee for the tyme being etcaetera
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand; the same hand that added the next item.
Full transcription, as in Mooney (1995), p. 111.

listBibl.bibl: Reginald Sharpe, Calendar of letter-books preserved among the archives of the Corporation of the City of London at the Guildhall. Letter Book L, Circa A.D. Temp Edward IV-Henry VII (London: 1912), p. 214

msItem.title: Condition of Recognisance of freemen of the City of London
msItem.rubric: 45v The condicioun of Recougnisaunce of free men etcaetera
msItem.incipit: 45v The condicioun of this recougnisaunce is suche that if the said A. B. as long as he shall joy or clayme to joy the liberte of the said cittee he shalbe continually abydyng with his howshold within the said cittee or the suburbes of the same
msItem.explicit: 45v And also if [crossed out: be] spesially and principally occupie the craft or myster of .l. to the whiche he is admitted more than any other craft / if any within the said citte he will occupie or it shall happen hym to occupie than this recougnysaunce be had for nought or elles stond in full strenght and vertue
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand; the same hand that added the previous item.

msItem.title: The manner and form of Coronation for kings and queens of England
msItem.rubric: 46r The maner and forme of the Coronacioun of Kynges and Qweenes of Inglond
msItem.incipit: 46r First the Prince that is newe to be corowned the day bifore his Coronacioun shalbe apparailed and clothed with most noble and fairest clothyng and so he shal ride from the Towr of london vnto his paleys of westmynster thurghout þe citee of london barehed ridyng with hym temporal lordis and the communalte of the same citee with other moche and noble people
msItem.explicit: 50v Also he shalbe nygh and bi the kynges side til the service of the Coronacioun be fully endid and fulfilled

msItem.title: Of the liberties and priviliges in the City of London
msItem.rubric: 61r Off the libertees and ffraunchices in the Citee of london in the tyme of Seynt Edward kyng of Inglond
msItem.incipit: 61r Has it conteyneth in the lawe of seynt edward capitulo xlvio that it owith in london whiche is the hede of the realme and of lawe and alwey the court of our lord the kyng every wike on the moneday . Hustyng to sitte . and to beholde . fforsoth sumtyme was founded and edified at the instaunce and nygh to the symilitude of grete Troie and to the maner and memory in itsilf
msItem.explicit: 65r And if the maisters of the Brigge denye to drawe the Brigge whan thei bien duely requyred for .vj. pence so as it is saide than thei to forfete .iiij. shillinges iiij pence to thuse of the chamber of the proper goodis of the saide maisters to be levied etcaetera
msItem.finalRubric: 65r Thomas cooke of london maire entred in the booke marked with the letter .L. the leef .xliiij.
msItem.note: For further details about the contents of this text, see Mooney (1995), p. 111.

msItem.title: Alphabet of legal and everyday terms
msItem.textLang: Middle English, Old English, and Celtic
msItem.rubric: 65r Thexposiciouns of Vowels as wel of Britouns as of Saxons in dyvers parties in the Realme of Inglond
msItem.incipit: 65r-65v Thexposiciouns of vowels as wel of bretons as of saxons in divers parties of inglond vsed aldermanni that is to say eldermen nat for their age but for their wisdam abremurde that is to say open murther or proved abasue that is say passage auerpany that is to say to be quyte of peny yevyng for arrerage of the kyng
msItem.explicit: 67r Nota that grene in briton tunge is cald glas in inglissh shield is cald tarcan

msItem.title: Note on the foundation of London and Rome
msItem.incipit: 67r London was made in the last yere of Brute and Rome þe first yeere of Cunedage so Rome after the foundacioun ccc vj yeeere space and so to vnderstonde that rome is of latter makyng þan london vnderstonde from the compassyng aboute the wallis and of the names that remus and romulus and nat at the first foundacioun for whi bifore that brute was bore grete part of rome was founded as in the cronicles of rome lightly may be shewed
msItem.note: Full transcription as in Mooney (1995), p. 111.

msItem.title: Note on the origins of St Peter's Church, Cornhill
msItem.incipit: 67r Nota that the temple of accorde now is a chirche founded in the worship of the prince of apostels bi kyng lucie the whiche now is cald seynt petir vpon cornhill
msItem.note: Full transcription, almost as in Mooney (1995), pp. 111-112 [Mooney transcribes: kyng lune].
An added marginal note reader: Stow. An. 39.

msItem.title: Note on a law of Ine, King of Wessex, regarding legal age for thieves to be prosecuted
msItem.incipit: 67r In the lawe of ine kyng of westsaxouns a chield of .x. yeere old ought to knowe that he dide no theft
msItem.note: Full transcription as in Mooney (1995), p. 112.

msItem.title: Collection of customs, rights, and privileges of portions and of various guilds of London [English version of Anglo-Norman Liber Albus
msItem.rubric: 67r Ancient Customes that the Kyng ought to take of marchaundices in London
msItem.incipit: 67r The baale greyn that peiseth .CCC. pounds owith to scavage .iij. shillinges .iiij. pence
msItem.explicit: 85v-86r and thow shalt do non extorciouns ne wronges to man ne to womman of this warde bi colour of thyn office ne mayntene no quarels agenst the right but weele and triewly kepe and mayntene þe kynges pees in this warde and do triewly and wele to þe poore as to the riche to thi power so help the god and holydom
msItem.note: For further details on this text, see Mooney (1995), p. 112.

msItem.title: Laws governing the sheriffs' court in London
msItem.incipit: 87r ffirst it is to wite that the shereves of london shuldn hold the courtis of our lord the kyng bifore hem in the Guyldhall of london and plees of dette of whatsumever somme and of al other accions personels at te sute of parties and everiche of the saide shereves holde his court at the saide Guyldhall bi hymsilf severally and bi the vertu of the pleintes and quarels made bifore that oon and that other of the sant shereves
msItem.explicit: 96r And how be it that suche a fermer withynne the saide citee do felony or other contempt for whiche his goodis and chatels bien arrested or forfetable yit the lessour bi vsage of the citee shalbe served of his ferme behynde bi .ij. yeere as is biforsaide of goodis founden withyn the same house
msItem.note: Note on actions of account added in purple ink to the margin of f. 95r in a near-contemporary hand.

msItem.title: Statute of Servants
msItem.rubric: 100r The statue of seruauntis made the xxiiij yeere of Kyng Edward .iij.
msItem.incipit: 100r It is ordeyned that every man or womman of whatsumever state of condicioun that he be free seruile or bonde of condicioun myghti in body withynne the age of .lx. yeere nat livyng bi marchaundyse nor exercisyng any certayne craft nor havyng of his owne wherof they mown live nor lond of their owne of the whiche tilth thei mown be occupied and seruant to nonother . If to seruice he be required be he hold to serve hym whiche hym huyreth and takith his wagis þat in placis wher hym ought to serve and wont to be don the yeere of our reigne .xx. precedent
msItem.explicit: 100v And for whi many strong mendivauntes beggers renyed and denyen to laboure aslong while as they mown live of almes It is ordeyned that noman vnder colour of pitee presume to savour hem in their subsidie or help vnder and vpon the peyne of enprisonement
msItem.note: First item of a legal casebook.

msItem.title: A deed of gift of goods
msItem.rubric: 100v A deede of yift of goodis
msItem.incipit: 100v To al triew cristen people to whom thiese present lettres comen by .J. N. gretyng al yowr vniuersite knowith me the forsaide j hath yeven graunted and to this my present writyng confermed to .T. G. al my goodis moevable and vnmoevable as wel the quike as dede withynne the towne of .M. or elliswhere withynne the realme of Inglond wherever they mown be founde
msItem.explicit: 100v And in the name of sisyne and possessioun of the forsaide goodis I have delivered to the forsaide .T. G. a parcel in ful and pesible possessioun of the same in witnesse of whiche thyng etcaetera
msItem.note: Second item of a legal casebook.

msItem.title: Plaint on Trespass
msItem.rubric: 100v A playnt of trespas vpon cas
msItem.incipit: 100v-101r Richard Thorp playneth vpon john vlceby of plee of trespas and wherof the saide pleintief bi his attorney saith that as he with hym in the vigile of ascencioun of our lord the yeere of kyng henry the sixt after the conquest of Inglond .xxvij. at beverley withyn the see and fraunchice of the lord john Cardynal and Archebisshop of york with the saide defendaunt bargayned that suche an hors of the saide pleintief price of .xx. shillinges in suche a close of pasture of the saide defendaunt there sauf and sure to feede graase and agifte from the saide vigile vnto the holy Trynite than next folowyng to paie to the saide defendaunt .CC. every tyme and what sumever tyme the saide pleintief the saide horse toke out of the forsaide pasture
msItem.explicit: 101r To that the saide pleintief bi his forsaide attorney saith that to this plee maner and fourme pleated no lawe puttith hym to aunswere Therfor for defaute of aunswer he askith iugement etcaetera
msItem.note: Third item of a legal casebook; relates to events in Beverley, Yorkshire, 21 May 1449.

msItem.title: Plea of debt pursued by executors
msItem.rubric: 101r Plee of dette or duete pursued bi executours
msItem.incipit: 101v Nicholas Brampton sone of John Brampton of Beverly marchaunt William Spencer John Steton Executours of the testament of the forsaide John Brampton playnen on John Bedforth of kyngeston vpon hull marchaunt of plee that he yield .lxij. pounds the whiche he theym vniustly witholdith
msItem.explicit: 101v at whiche fest the forsaide defandaunt often tymes lawfully required of the saide lxij pounds to the saide John Brampton nat paid after whos deth etcaetera
msItem.note: Fourth item of a legal casebook.

msItem.title: Definitions of legal terms
msItem.incipit: 101v Sute seruice: svte seruice is at the court from .iij. wikes into .iij. wikes bi þe yeere and for this a man shal be distressed in the grace of the lord and nat amercied
msItem.explicit: 103r fflemenfrith: fflemenfrith this is that ye have the catels of your men tenamentis sugitiefs and dampned etcaetera

msItem.title: Legal casebook
msItem.incipit: 103r A man holdith of a lord bi certayne seruice and rent and ceasith bi .ij. yeere his issue entrith and puttith out the fader and attournyth to the lord the rent is behynde the tenant disclaymeth the lord bryngeth a writ of right after the disclayme and recoverith the fader bryngeth assise
msItem.explicit: 122r and in [r]ight the saide tenaunt his wife and so seised of suche estate died seised after whos deth the said pleintief supposith that his fader at tyme of his
msItem.note: Many of the briefs pertain to people and places in Dale and Aldermaston in Devonshire. Others involve Kent, Berkshire, and Middlesex. The last case is incomplete.

msItem.title: Jubilee Book or new book of ordinances of the city of London, 1 Richard II
msItem.rubric: 133r La proheme del The proheme in the newe booke of thauncient customs and vsages in the Citee of London compiled and affermed bi the maire aldermen and comunes of the same Citee the yeere of kyng Richard the secunde the first yeere
msItem.incipit: 133r [T]he perfeccioun of al policie and the grounde of goode gouernaunce dwellen and abiden vpon .ij. thynges the whiche ne mown nat be disseuered ne departed but alwey toguyder to be hold and kept
msItem.explicit: 157r Other articles in the same charter content for vs and our heires of certein causis at the instaunce of the saide citezenis vttirly we adnulle
msItem.note: For further details on this text, see Mooney (1995), p. 133.

msItem.title: Oath for Richard Reynolds for his appointment of Sheriff of London, 1532
msItem.rubric: 158rThe oth that Richard Reynold mercer tok at the yeldhall when he was chosen shryve of london in anno 1532
msItem.incipit: 158r Ye shall swere that ye shalbe good and trew avnto our soueraign lord the kyng of Inglond . and to his heris kynges and the franches of this cyte of london within and withowt ye shall save and mayntayn to your power and ye shall well and truly kepe the sherys of london and medilsex and thoffices that to the same sheres pertaynen to be doon well and lawfull
msItem.explicit: 158r-158v ye shall kepe from harme after your pour and the shere of medilsex . in the gaole of newgate ye shall not let to farme and all the ordinanunces by the mair aldermen and commen cownsell made not repellid well and lawfully . ye shall kepe and do to be kept . as god yow help . and all sayntes and by this bok
msItem.note: Copied by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Regulations for poulterers (1521)
msItem.rubric: 158v Cor. consilium temp. die veneris videlicit quinto die Julij anno Regni Regis Henrrci viijm xiij in presenc. Johannis Brugge militis maioris
msItem.incipit: 158v Item for as moche as dyuerse and many of the pulters of this cyte distryt fully arrey their seruanttes lyke vnto husbandmen of the countrey and the same so aperielid sent as well into chepesyd to the market ther as into other markettes within this cyte with vitaylles corrupt lern and vnholsom for mans body and ther distrytfully sell and vtter the same to the gret dissayte of the kynges leige
msItem.explicit: 158v it is also firther agreid and fully concludyd by the same auctorite that they nor any of them by them selfes wifes or servauntes take apon them to by or regrate in any of the said markettes of this cyte any maner of pultie wares of any foren apon lyke payn etcaetera
msItem.note: Added by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Notice of payments due to curates of London, according to a bull purchased from Pope Nicholas
msItem.incipit: 177v In the bull of pope Nicholas purcheced by the curates of london for the oblacions among other it is contayned thus ffirst for euery inhabitaunt and householder within the said cette and franches of the same that is the rent of .x. shillinges by yere shall pay to god and to his curate euery offeryng day in the yere a ferthyng
msItem.explicit: 177v and the said curates be bounde by vertue of obedience to declare the said bull iiij tymes in the yere to there parisschens etcaetera

msItem.title: Deposition of John Forster concerning release by Dame Agnes Forster of her servant Thomas Holbeche so that he could return to his home, the manor of Mullesworth, for Christmas (c. 1485)
msItem.incipit: 178r John fforster of the pariche of alhalowyn in the wall in london draper of thage of l yere sworon and examyned the day and yere abveseid sayth and deposith that in the first yere of the reign of king richard iijde vppon ij or iij days before cristemas he was then in the place of dame annes fforster wedow in a highe chambre
msItem.explicit: 178r And the seid deponent seith that he was not priuy to noo delyuere of the seid relese otherwyse than he hathe aboue deposed and more he cannot sey in this mater etcaetera
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Heading for a medical recipe to treat bruises, incomplete
msItem.rubric: 178r A provysyon maed for all manner brouces
msItem.note: Full transcription as in Mooney (1995), p. 114. Added by a late 15th- or early 16th-centuruy hand.

msItem.title: Bond obligating Thomas Robinson, Carpenter, to pay William Clerk, Carpenter, dated to February 1493/4
msItem.incipit: 178v Nouerint vniversi per presentes me Willhelmum Clerke Ciuem et Carpenter london teneri et firmiter obligari Thome Robynson Ciui eciam et Carpenter London in quadraginta solidie legalis monete anglie soluendum eidem Thome
msItem.explicit: 178v presens oblicacio pro nullo habeatur sin autem in omni suo robore stet et effectu

supportDesc.support:
Paper, folded in folio. Folios [iii]-[iv]: Church (see Barron and Wright (2020) for a further discussion of this watermark and its occurence in another manuscript copied by the Hammond Scribe: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.52).
Folios 1-124, 128-132, 157: Hand with six-pointed star.
Folio 125: Scissors.
Folios 126-127, 133-156, 158-178: Letter P.

foliation.p: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the recto.
Folios [i]-[iii] and [iv] are early modern blank paper flyleaves; folio [a] is an original parchment flyleaf.
foliation.note: Numbers and letters are here allocated to unfoliated leaves for reference purposes in this electronic catalogue record.

foliation.p: Written in dark ink with a red paraph mark (until f. 122r) in the upper left-hand corners of the versos or right-hand corners of the rectos of each leaf.

signatures.p: 15th- or 16th-century quire signatures in brown and purple ink on the lower outer corners of the first rectos of quires, excluding Quires 1-2, featuring the table of contents, and Quires 13-16: Quire 3 = a; Quire 4 = b; Quire 5 = c; Quire 6 = d; Quire 7 = e; Quire 8 = f; Quire 9 = g; Quire 10 = h; Quire 11 = j; Quire 12 = k.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords written at the center in the lower margins of the last versos of quires.

supportDesc.condition: The front board is loosely attached. The lower half of f. 133 is largely torn off. Large tears in ff. 152 (lower margin), 61 (lower margin), and 122 (upper outer margin). The manuscript features one loose straw between f. 75 and f. 76.

layout.seg: Ruled in red ink, frame and line ruling. Single columns. 35 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Folios 1v-157r and 177v-178v are copied by a scribe in a cursive hand with both anglicana and secretary features from the reign of Edward IV; the scribe, known as the Hammond Scribe, is also the principal hand in Cambridge, Trinity College MS R.14.52 and the second hand in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.3.21. To date, their hand has been identified in fifteen manuscripts. (see Mooney (1995), p. 109).
Medical recipes on f. [a] verso are copied by a late 15th- or early 16th-century cursive hand in a cursive script with both secretary and anglicana features.
Folios 158r-158v are copied by two late 15th- or early 16th-century cursive hands working in a secretary script with some anglicana features.

decoNote.p: Large (3 lines) red in initials in frameworks of blue penwork decoration with pen-flourishing in the same colour extending into the margins. However, blank spaces and guide letters show that such initials were planned but never finished for the text from f. 133r onwards.
Small (1 line) initials in red ink.
Titles and sub-headings written in red ink.
Initials in brown ink highlighted with red ink.

note.p: Note of the manuscript's contents in Roger Gale's 17th-century hand on f. [iii] recto.
Title inscription for the manuscript's contents (Customs of London) in a 17th-century hand on f. [a] recto.

binding.p: 17th-century brown speckled leather over pasteboards; the spine with 5 raised bands a red leather label with the gold-stamped inscription: Customs of London and, below that, M.S.. Three paper labels with the alpha-numerical elements of the current classmark printed separately (O, 3, 11) are pasted onto the spine.

origin.origDate: Copied c. 1450-1483 by the so-called Hammond Scribe.

provenance.p: Sir Thomas Cook (b. c. 1410, d. 1478) Cook, Thomas, Sir, b. c. 1410-1478, draper and mayor of London (1462-63) and father-in-law of John Forster (see below): perhaps the manuscript's commisioner and first owner. A text on the liberties and privileges of the City of London refers to a book owned by Thomas Cooke (f. 65r). For further discussion of his connection with this manuscript, see Barron and Wright (2020), pp. 1, 27-30.

John Forster (d. 1488) Forster, John, d. 1488, son of the London alderman and mayor Stephen Forster and son-in-law of Sir Thomas Cook (see above): perhaps added his deposition of 1483 to f. 178r. For further discussion of his connection with this manuscript, see Barron and Wright (2020), pp. 1, 27-30.

One of the manuscripts of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635/6-1702, dean of York, antiquary and fellow of Trinity College Cambridge. The manuscript is listed as no. 316 (see f. 1r) in the list of Gale's manuscripts in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697).

One of the manuscripts of Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, antiquary and scholar, son of Thomas Gale. Inherited from his father. A letter signed R. Gale and with a red wax seal featuring the Gale coat of arms on f. [iii] recto: There is extant in Print, about the time of Henry the 7th a Booke of the Customes of London. It reckoneth the begining of the Bailiffes custoses Shereffes of London from about the begining of the reigne of Richard the first. It agreeth with this Booke in some fer things. But this is far better.

history.acquisition: Donated to Trinity College by Roger Gale (1672-1744)Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, son of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702), in 1738. The alpha-numerical elements of its current classmark are printed on three (much worn) labels pasted onto the spine (O.3.11), and those of its current and previous classmarks are inscribed in the manuscript: inside of the front cover (O.9.32 in pencil); f. [a] recto (O.3.11 - Customs of London and H.2. [crossed out], and O.10.6 [crossed out]) Its printed ex libris featuring its armorial coat of arms, motto (Virtus Vera Nobilitas) and name (Coll: Trin: Cant:) pasted on the inside of the front cover. Its modern library stamp on ff. [a] verso, 1r, 178v.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College, Cambridge: a descriptive catalogue, 3 (1902); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995).

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.
